pageData.text: Biological macromolecules are large, complex organic molecules that are synthesized and used by living organisms. These biological macromolecules can be divided into four categories: carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids. Food consists of these molecules. Biological macromolecules cannot pass through the intestinal wall unless they are converted to smaller molecules by digestive <button class='glossary-text'>enzymes</button>. In this investigation, you will perform standard chemical tests for carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids. Then you will model enzymatic digestion of protein and starch under conditions simulating the stomach and intestines. The effects of temperature and pH on enzymatic activity will also be tested.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Carbohydrate source such as sugar, fruit, vegetable juice, or bread
Protein source such as meat, milk, beans, or tofu
Food samples such as cheese, meat, vegetables, or potatoes
Digital camera or mobile device with camera

Activity 5: Modeling Salivary Digestion of Starch - 10 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Biological Macromolecules and Enzymes

text: Describe the function of <button class='glossary-text'>enzymes</button> in the digestion of food.
Describe the chemical composition of carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids.
Describe the chemical tests performed on food and explain the results.
Model the gastric digestion of protein and evaluate the effect of pH on the process.
Model the salivary digestion of starch.

pageData.text: Entomophagy is eating insects. It is estimated that over 2 billion people worldwide meet their daily nutrition requirements with insects. It has been suggested that hunters and gatherers probably learned which insects were edible by observing what other animals ate. Although insects remain popular in many traditional cuisines in Africa, Asia, and Latin America, many people in western cultures find the idea of eating insects less appealing.The United Nations published a report in 2013 that suggested that to combat climate change and feed an ever-growing human population, we should eat insects. Insects reproduce quickly, have high feed conversion and growth rates, a low environmental footprint, and are extremely nutritious. Approximately 95% of a grasshopper is edible and contains, and about 100 grasshoppers contain 30 g of protein, 3.8 g of fat, numerous vitamins and minerals, and chitin, which is a prebiotic fiber that may help maintain a healthy gut microbiome. Compare this to a cow, of which only about 45% is edible, a 3.0 oz (~85 g) sirloin steak contains 22 g of protein, 3 g of fat, Vitamin D, Vitamin B6, and Cobalamin, but no dietary fiber.

ReferenceThe State of Food Insecurity in the World 2013: The multiple dimensions of food security. (2013). Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), and the World Food Programme (WFP).https://reliefweb.int/report/world/state-food-insecurity-world-2013-multiple-dimensions-food-security

pageData.desc: A person using chopsticks to fill a cup with insect pupae
pageData.altText: A person using chopsticks to fill a cup with insect pupae

pageData.text: The main functions of the digestive system are mechanical and chemical digestion, and absorption. Digestion is the process in which the body breaks food down into smaller molecules so that nutrients can be easily absorbed. The entire digestion process can take anywhere from 24 to 50 hours.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Digestive System

pageData.subTitle: Mouth/Esophagus
pageData.text: Digestion begins in the mouth through the mechanical and chemical breakdown of food. Smooth muscle tissue in the esophagus squeezes the food down toward the stomach in a process called peristalsis.

pageData.subTitle: Stomach
pageData.text: Mechanical and chemical digestion continues in the stomach. Smooth muscle tissue in the stomach wall squeezes and churns the material, while <button class='glossary-text'>enzymes</button> and chemicals are added to help further break down the food.

pageData.subTitle: Stomach structure
pageData.text: The internal structure of the stomach has ridges and folds called rugae. This increases the surface area within the stomach and allows it to expand to hold more food.

pageData.subTitle: Intestines
pageData.text: The small intestine and large intestine (colon) combined average 25 feet long.

pageData.subTitle: Small Intestine
pageData.text: The majority of absorption takes place in the small intestine, which is about 20 feet long. The small intestine has 3 sections: duodenum, jejunum, and ileum.Finger-like extensions called villi and microvilli increase the surface area of the small intestine, allowing maximum absorption of nutrients and water.

pageData.altText: Small Intestine

pageData.subTitle: <span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Large Intestine
pageData.text: The large intestine, about 5 feet long, is responsible for eliminating waste matter.

pageData.altText: Large Intestine

pageData.text: Food is absorbed by the digestive system only after it is broken down into smaller molecules. As food passes through the digestive tract, it is broken down into increasingly smaller components through physical digestion processes. Chemical digestion is performed by that break larger molecules down into smaller, less complex units called , which can be absorbed. The exact digestive processes, the reaction locations in the digestive tract, and how the body uses the monomers all depend on the molecular composition of the food. The four groups of biological macromolecules broken down during digestion are carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids.

pageData.subTitle: Carbohydrates
pageData.text: Carbohydrates are organic compounds that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the general formula (CH2O)n. The biological process of cellular respiration breaks down carbohydrates to yield energy for cellular activity. Carbohydrates also provide a source of carbon for use in the synthesis of many structural materials. Carbohydrates can be classified into three categories based on molecular structure: , , and . Monosaccharides are the of carbohydrates. They are the least complex of the carbohydrate molecules and are often called “simple sugars.” Examples of monosaccharides are glucose, fructose, ribose, and deoxyribose. Disaccharides contain two chemically bonded monosaccharides, and include sucrose (table sugar), maltose, and lactose. Polysaccharides are the most complex carbohydrates, and contain several monosaccharides linked in various configurations (Figure 1). Starches, cellulose, chitin, and glycogen are polysaccharides.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: The molecular structures of starch, which is either chain-like or branched; glycogen, which is highly branched; and cellulose, which is like a sheet of chain-like molecules.

pageData.question: What is the general formula of a carbohydrate?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Carbohydrates are organic compounds that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the general formula (CH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O)<sub class=bodySubscript>n</sub>.

pageData.question: Which of the following chemical reactions best describes the process of aerobic cellular respiration?

options.text: C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub> + O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> --> ATP + H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O + CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>
C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub> --> O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> + ATP

C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub> + H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O --> O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> + CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>
O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> + ATP --> C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub> + CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>
CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> + H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O --> C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In the presence of oxygen (O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>), mitochondria break down glucose (C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>) into ATP, water (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O) and carbon dioxide (CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Carbohydrates are organic compounds that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the general formula (CH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O)<sub class=bodySubscript>n</sub>. When carbohydrates are consumed, the body breaks them down into glucose (C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>).  The transformation of glucose into energy occurs in one of two ways: with oxygen or without it. In mitochondria and in the presence of oxygen (O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>), glucose is converted to energy, or adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This conversion yields not only ATP, but also heat, water (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O), and carbon dioxide (CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Carbohydrates are organic compounds that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the general formula (CH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O)<sub class=bodySubscript>n</sub>. When carbohydrates are consumed, the body breaks them down into glucose (C<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>12</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>6</sub>).  The transformation of glucose into energy occurs in one of two ways: with oxygen or without it. In mitochondria and in the presence of oxygen (O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>), glucose is converted to energy, or adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This conversion yields not only ATP, but also heat, water (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O), and carbon dioxide (CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>).

pageData.subTitle: Proteins
pageData.text: Proteins are complex organic compounds composed of <button class='glossary-text'>monomers</button> called <button class='glossary-text'>amino acids</button>. Amino acids contain hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen in the general chemical formula NH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>–RCH–COOH, where –R represents hydrogen, a functional group, a carbon chain, or a carbon ring structure (Figure 2). All amino acids are identical except for the –R group. The properties of each amino acid depend on the –R group structure. All organisms require nitrogen for the construction of proteins, nucleic acids, and other compounds. Some microorganisms can convert organic nitrogen into amine (–NH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>), which is used in the biosynthesis of amino acids. Twenty amino acids are encoded by the universal genetic code; these are known as the natural amino acids. These 20 amino acids can be linked together by <button class='glossary-text'>peptide bonds</button> to form proteins. The linked amino acids can form dipeptides, tripeptides, and <button class='glossary-text'>polypeptides</button>. The polypeptides may contain any number, sequence, and/or configuration of amino acids to form a vast number of proteins. Thus, the proteins contained in foods are a source of prefabricated amino acid groups. Although some amino acids can be synthesized in the human body, the “essential” amino acids must be supplied in prefabricated form via the diet. Nine amino acids are considered essential. The absence of any of these halts the synthesis of crucial proteins, resulting in disease, and, in prolonged cases of deprivation, death.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: The chemical structure of an amino acid.

pageData.subTitle: Lipids
pageData.text: Lipids are a diverse group of organic compounds that are classified together because they are soluble in organic solvents (e.g., alcohol, ether, benzene, and acetone), but insoluble in water. Similar to carbohydrates, lipids are composed of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen; however, the percentage of oxygen is much lower. Phospholipids contain a phosphorus in addition to C, H, and O. Lipids include , steroids, phospholipids, waxes, and other lipoid substances. Lipids are used primarily for energy and for structural purposes. Triglycerides, also known as neutral fats, provide organisms with a concentrated source of energy, yielding twice as many calories per gram as carbohydrates and proteins. They contain three chains bonded to a glycerol molecule (a sugar alcohol). Fatty acids are if they contain only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain and are generally solid at room temperature. Fatty acids are if they contain one or more double bonds between carbons in the chain and are generally liquid at room temperature (Figure 3).

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A saturated fatty acid molecule on top and an unsaturated fatty acid molecule on bottom.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the chemical structure of a saturated fatty acid?

options.text: It contains only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain.
It contains one or more double bonds between carbons in the chain.
It contains two or more triple bonds between carbons in the chain.
It contains more than three fatty acid chains bonded to a glycerol molecule.
It contains only one fatty acid chain bonded to a glycerol molecule.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Fatty acids are saturated if they contain only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain and are generally solid at room temperature.

pageData.question: The terms “saturated” and “unsaturated”, when describing fatty acids, refer to what chemical element?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The term saturated indicates that the maximum possible number of hydrogen atoms are bonded to each carbon. An unsaturated fatty acid will have fewer hydrogen atoms than a saturated fatty acid of the same chain length.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Fatty acids are saturated if they contain only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain and are generally solid at room temperature. The term saturated indicates that the maximum possible number of hydrogen atoms are bonded to each carbon. Fatty acids are unsaturated if they contain one or more double bonds between carbons in the chain and are generally liquid at room temperature. When three fatty acid chains are bonded to a glycerol molecule, the lipid is known as triglyceride. They provide organisms with a concentrated source of energy, yielding twice as many calories per gram as carbohydrates and proteins. Other examples of lipids include steroids, phospho-lipids, waxes, and other lipoid substances.

img.alt: Figure 3: A saturated fatty acid molecule on top and an unsaturated fatty acid molecule on bottom.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Fatty acids are saturated if they contain only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain and are generally solid at room temperature. The term saturated indicates that the maximum possible number of hydrogen atoms are bonded to each carbon. Fatty acids are unsaturated if they contain one or more double bonds between carbons in the chain and are generally liquid at room temperature. When three fatty acid chains are bonded to a glycerol molecule, the lipid is known as triglyceride. They provide organisms with a concentrated source of energy, yielding twice as many calories per gram as carbohydrates and proteins. Other examples of lipids include steroids, phospho-lipids, waxes, and other lipoid substances.

img.alt: Figure 3: A saturated fatty acid molecule on top and an unsaturated fatty acid molecule on bottom.

pageData.subTitle: Nucleic Acids
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Deoxyribonucleic acid</button> (DNA) and <button class='glossary-text'>ribonucleic acid</button> (RNA) are biologically important nucleic acids, which function to store and transmit genetic information. Nucleic acids are composed of <button class='glossary-text'>monomers</button> called <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotides</button>. Generally, nucleotides are composed of a sugar, a nitrogenous base, and phosphate. <button class='glossary-text'>Adenosine triphosphate</button> (ATP) is a nucleotide consisting of a sugar, a nitrogenous base, and three phosphate groups. ATP is known as the “molecular currency” of intracellular energy because it stores chemical energy within cells. Other nucleotides have biological significance due to their function in specific biochemical pathways. Although nucleic acids and nucleotides are present in foods, they are not usually considered as key molecules in digestion and nutrient absorption. Consequently, their digestion will not be discussed in detail here.

pageData.subTitle: Enzymes Aid in Digestion
pageData.text: Most chemical reactions in living organisms would be too slow to sustain life if they were not mediated by specialized proteins called <button class='glossary-text'>enzymes</button>. Enzymes act as catalysts to speed up chemical reactions by lowering the activation energy required for the reaction (Figure 4). Activation energy is the minimum amount of energy required to start a chemical reaction. In the case of digestion, enzymes catalyze the chemical reactions that break down carbohydrates, protein, and fats.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Graph depicting the relationship between energy required in order to convert chemical reactants to products. Less energy is required in the presence of an enzyme to catalyze the reaction.

pageData.subTitle: Enzymes Aid in Digestion (cont... )
pageData.text: An enzyme activity is specific for a reaction or a set of reactions. Each enzyme binds exclusively to the substrate or substrates of the reaction(s) it catalyzes. This specific binding occurs because the shape of the enzyme specifically fits or interlocks with the shape of one or more substrates, forming the enzyme-substrate complex (Figure 5). The enzyme catalyst remains unchanged by the reaction. When the reaction is complete and the enzyme is no longer bound to the substrate(s), the enzyme returns to its original form. The analogy of a “lock and key” was historically used to describe the enzyme-substrate complex. The enzyme has a binding pocket, called an active site, which is shaped to fit a specific substrate. Although this analogy is conceptually helpful, it is somewhat limited. The enzyme-substrate complex is now described by the “induced fit” model, which accounts for the potential shape change of the enzyme when it is bound to its substrate.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram showing a substrate and enzyme coming together to form an enzyme-substrate complex, and the products separating from the enzyme.

pageData.subTitle: Enzymes Aid in Digestion (cont... )
pageData.text: Various biotic and abiotic factors can influence enzyme activity. <button class='glossary-text'>Enzymes</button> in living organisms operate best within a narrow range of conditions, including specific temperatures, substrate and product concentrations, salinity, and pH. For example, the human digestive system utilizes several enzymes to break down food. Different enzymes operate in different parts of the digestive tract. Some parts of the digestive tract are acidic (pH < 7), whereas other parts are alkaline or basic (pH > 7). Because enzymes are proteins, a shift in pH or other environmental factors may cause denaturation (loss of normal structure), resulting in the loss of a functional active site.

There may be other molecules that help or hinder enzyme activity and efficiency by binding to the substrate. Coenzymes and cofactors are activators that increase reaction rates. Cofactors are small inorganic compounds and ions, whereas coenzymes are organic molecules such as vitamins.

Inhibitor molecules may block the enzyme active site and prevent substrate binding, either permanently or temporarily. Competitive inhibitors are molecules that have a charge and conformation that allows them to reversibly bind the enzyme active site and prevent substrate binding. Competitive inhibitors affect the initial reaction rate but not the maximum reaction rate. Noncompetitive inhibitors bind to regions other than the enzyme active site; this binding causes an enzyme conformational change so that the substrate can no longer bind to the active site. Noncompetitive inhibitors reduce the maximum rate of reaction.

pageData.question: Historically, the “lock and key” analogy was used to describe the enzyme-substrate complex. Now, it is commonly described by the induced-fit model. Which of the following best describes an enzyme in an enzyme-substrate complex, according to the induced-fit model?

options.text: An enzyme may change its shape when binding to a substrate.
Each enzyme has an active site that exactly fits its substrate.
An enzyme can bind to any molecule in the environment by modifying its active site.
An enzyme will deactivate after binding to its substrate.
The shape of an enzyme is permanently changed after binding to a substrate.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The enzyme has a binding pocket, called an active site, which is shaped to fit a specific substrate. However, an enzyme may change shape slightly when it is bound to a substrate.

pageData.question: Which of the following is most likely to happen to an enzyme that is exposed to an environmental change, such as a change in temperature?

options.text: The enzyme changes shape and becomes non-functional.
The enzyme changes its active site and binds to new substrates.
The enzyme becomes dependent on cofactors to function.
The enzyme’s active site assumes a shape more specific to its substrate.
The enzyme migrates to a more ideal environment.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Because enzymes are proteins, a shift in pH or other environmental factors may cause denaturation (loss of normal structure), resulting in the loss of a functional active site.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In this simulation, the amplified fragments of DNA contain the region known to have the sickle cell mutation, but it is unknown if the mutation is present or absent. Remember, the nucleotides, and thus the mutation, are much too small to visualize. Therefore, molecular tools are needed to determine if the mutation is present. Among these tools are restriction endonucleases, also called restriction enzymes. Restriction endonucleases are enzymes that act like tiny scissors that can cut DNA at specific nucleotide sequences, such as the location of a mutation. The dyes you are given in this investigation represent simulated DNA samples that have been amplified and treated with a restriction enzyme that cuts at the location of the sickle cell mutation. When each sample is visualized using gel electrophoresis, the number of bands and their sizes indicate the presence or absence of restriction sites within the amplified DNA.

img.alt: Figure 5: Diagram showing a substrate and enzyme coming together to form an enzyme-substrate complex, and the products separating from the enzyme.

Remember, the nucleotides, and thus the mutation, are much too small to visualize. Therefore, molecular tools are needed to determine if the mutation is present. Among these tools are restriction endonucleases, also called restriction enzymes. Restriction endonucleases are enzymes that act like tiny scissors that can cut DNA at specific nucleotide sequences, such as the location of a mutation. The dyes you are given in this investigation represent simulated DNA samples that have been amplified and treated with a restriction enzyme that cuts at the location of the sickle cell mutation. When each sample is visualized using gel electrophoresis, the number of bands and their sizes indicate the presence or absence of restriction sites within the amplified DNA.

pageData.subTitle: Digestive Processes
pageData.text: Digestion begins in the mouth with mastication, or chewing. Mastication grinds food into smaller pieces. At the same time, the food is mixed with saliva excreted from salivary glands in the mouth. Saliva contains the enzyme , which catalyzes the breakdown of starch into its component sugars (see Figure 6).

pageData.altText: Figure 6: The enzyme amylase catalyzes hydrolysis of starch to maltose with the addition of water.

pageData.text: The partially digested mass of food, called a bolus, moves from the mouth, through the esophagus by muscle action, and then reaches the stomach, where the process of gastric digestion occurs. During gastric digestion, glands in the stomach secrete <button class='glossary-text'>enzymes</button> and hydrochloric acid, which are mixed with the bolus by the churning action of muscles in the stomach wall. One of the enzymes, <button class='glossary-text'>pepsin</button>, catalyzes the reduction of proteins into polypeptides and <button class='glossary-text'>amino acids</button>. Pepsin requires a temperature of approximately 37 °C (i.e., body temperature) and low pH to catalyze this reaction. Hydrochloric acid serves to lower the pH, which inactivates and kills some potentially harmful microorganisms in the food. The product of gastric digestion in the stomach is a semiliquid called <button class='glossary-text'>chyme</button>.

The chyme exits the stomach and passes through the pyloric sphincter into the small intestine. There, it stimulates the production of alkaline intestinal fluids that counteract the acidity of the gastric products. When the acidic chyme becomes alkaline, gastric digestion ceases and intestinal digestion begins. Pancreatic juice, or <button class='glossary-text'>pancreatin</button>, is secreted by the pancreas into the duodenum. This liquid contains the enzymes amylase, trypsin, and <button class='glossary-text'>lipase</button>. The amylase in pancreatin, just like that in saliva, breaks down starches into their component sugars. Trypsin hydrolyzes <button class='glossary-text'>polypeptides</button>, converting them into amino acids. Lipase breaks down lipids (fats) into glycerol and <button class='glossary-text'>fatty acids</button>. However, lipids are not soluble in water and must first undergo the process of emulsification. Emulsification is not a chemical process (it does not break chemical bonds); rather, it reduces the attraction between fat molecules and disperses them so large droplets become small droplets that can more readily interact with the enzymes. Bile salts are emulsifiers that are produced by the liver to assist in the emulsification and digestion of lipids.

pageData.subTitle: Digestive Processes (cont... )
pageData.text: After the chemical breakdown of food in the stomach and small intestine, absorption of the molecules and nutrients must occur. Absorption is the passage of substances through the intestinal mucosa into the blood or lymph. The body cannot absorb proteins, starches, and fats without their first being broken down into their component <button class='glossary-text'>amino acids</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>monosaccharides</button>, and fatty acids. The majority of nutrient absorption occurs in the small intestine.

pageData.subTitle: Substrate Tests
pageData.text: In this investigation, you will test for the presence of certain biological macromolecules that serve as substrates for digestive <button class='glossary-text'>enzymes</button>: carbohydrates (specifically, starches), proteins, and lipids.

Starches can be identified by a simple test using iodine-potassium iodide. In the presence of starch, an iodine-potassium iodide solution changes color from bright yellow to dark blue or black. This color change results from iodine binding to the ends of the large starch molecules. The starch you will use in Activities 1 and 2 is derived from potatoes.

The protein test used in this kit is called the Biuret test. All compounds that contain <button class='glossary-text'>peptide bonds</button> will yield a positive result. Thus, all proteins and <button class='glossary-text'>polypeptides</button> give a positive test result, but individual amino acids do not. The Biuret reagent is made of sodium hydroxide and copper sulfate. This blue reagent turns purple in the presence of proteins and pink in the presence of amino acids. The albumin you will use in Activities 1 and 2 is a protein found in egg white.

Activity 3 is a quick and safe test for fats. This test uses paper, which can readily absorb lipids. This is indicated by the paper turning translucent and remaining that way once the sample has dried. In the absence of lipids, the dry brown paper will appear opaque.
In Activities 4 and 5, you will use the starch and protein tests to observe the action of enzymes on these substrates. You will also test the effects of pH and temperature on enzyme action.

pageData.question: In this investigation, you will test for the presence of certain macronutrients that serve as substrates for digestive enzymes. When iodine-potassium iodide solution changes color from bright yellow to dark blue or black, what type of molecule is present in the food sample?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This color change results from iodine binding to the ends of large starch molecules.

pageData.question: Which item on the list below is most likely to cause a dark blue or black color change in iodine-potassium iodide solution?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Polysaccharides are the most complex carbohydrates and will cause a color change in iodine-potassium iodide solution. These carbohydrates are found in food items like bread.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In this investigation, you will test for the presence of certain macronutrients that serve as substrates for digestive enzymes. Starches can be identified by a simple test using iodine-potassium iodide. In the presence of starch, an iodine-potassium iodide solution changes color from bright yellow to dark blue or black. The protein test used in this kit is called the Biuret test. All compounds that contain peptide bonds will yield a positive result. The blue Biuret reagent turns purple in the presence of proteins and pink in the presence of amino acids. You will also conduct a quick and safe test for fats. This test uses paper, which can readily absorb fats. This is indicated by the paper turning translucent and remaining that way once the sample has dried. In the absence of lipids, the dry brown paper will appear opaque.

Before starting any activities, prepare the test tubes, prepare starch, albumin, and pepsin solutions, and prepare paper squares. In Activity 1, you will conduct starch tests with controls, as well as three food samples. conduct protein tests with controls, as well as three food samples.  If so, yes go forward, if not go back. conduct quick tests for fats with eight food samples.  If so, yes go forward, if not go back. Model the gastric digestion of protein. In Activity 5, you will model the salivary digestion of starch.

content.altText: Plastic dropper bottle containing 15 milliliters of 0.1 molar hydrochloric acid

content.label: Pepsin powder, 0.5 g
content.altText: Small white container with black cap containing 0.5 gram Pepsin powder

content.label: Test tube rack
content.altText: White cardboard test tube rack, flat

text: Carbohydrate source such as sugar, fruit, vegetable juice, or bread
Protein source such as meat, milk, beans, or tofu
Food samples such as cheese, meat, vegetables, or potatoes
Digital camera or mobile device with camera

pageData.text: Reorder Information:Replacement supplies for the Biological Macromolecules and Enzymes investigation (item 580166) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Wear your safety goggles, chemical apron, and gloves at all times while conducting this investigation.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

pageData.altText: warning symbol
pageData.text: Biuret reagent, pepsin and iodine-potassium iodide can be harmful if swallowed and are serious eye irritants.

pageData.altText: corrosion symbol
pageData.text: Hydrochloric acid, Biuret reagent, and iodine-potassium iodide are corrosive materials. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eye wash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes.

pageData.altText: health hazard symbol
pageData.text: Pepsin may cause allergy or asthma symptoms if inhaled. Iodine-potassium iodide can cause an allergic skin reaction.

pageData.altText: toxic symbol
pageData.text: Hydrochloric acid is toxic if inhaled.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between an enzyme, a chemical reaction, and activation energy?

options.text: An enzyme catalyzes a chemical reaction by lowering its activation energy.
An enzyme catalyzes a chemical reaction by raising its activation energy.
An enzyme is produced by a chemical reaction when the activation energy is low.
An enzyme is produced by a chemical reaction when the activation energy is high.
An enzyme’s activation energy is lowered as it catalyzes a chemical reaction.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes the digestion that takes place in the mouth?

options.text: The mouth digests food chemically and mechanically.
The mouth digests food only chemically.
The mouth digests food only mechanically.
The mouth digests all foods chemically and only some foods mechanically.
The mouth does not participate in digestion.

assestmentData.question: The digestion of a protein into its monomer units would yield which of the following molecules?

Simon is making qualitative observations of a food sample at room temperature to identify any fats it may contain. Which of the following differences in the physical states of fat is Simon most likely looking for in the sample?

options.text: Saturated fats are solid; unsaturated fats are liquid.
Saturated fats are liquid; unsaturated fats are waxy.
Saturated fats are homogenous; unsaturated fats are heterogeneous.
Saturated fats are heterogeneous; unsaturated fats are homogenous.
Saturated fats are water soluble; unsaturated fats are not water soluble.

assestmentData.question: For this investigation, you will need to provide sources of which of the following types of macromolecules?

options.text: proteins, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and lipids

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a safety hazard associated with the Biuret reagent provided in your lab kit for this investigation?

options.text: It is a corrosive material and must be used near a safety shower.
It can cause an allergic skin reaction.
It can stain skin or clothing.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following reagents will need to be prepared prior to starting any of the activities in this investigation?
Where in the digestive tract does most of the nutrient absorption occur?
The albumin powder in this investigation serves as a positive control for which of the following molecules?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure for each activity.
Obtain all materials.
Clear the work area.
Label three test tubes 1–3 with the grease pencil.

Prepare the potato starch solution.
  1. Remove the outer cap and dropper cap from the plastic bottle labeled “Potato Starch.”
  2. Add distilled water to the bottle until it is filled to the neck, and then replace both caps.
  3. Shake the bottle gently until most of the potato starch powder is dissolved. The starch may not dissolve completely.

Prepare the albumin solution.
  1. Remove the outer cap and plastic dropper cap from the bottle labeled “Albumin Solution.”
  2. Add distilled water to the bottle until it is filled to the neck, and then replace both caps.
  3. Shake the bottle gently until most of the albumin powder is dissolved. The protein may not dissolve completely. Once the albumin solution is prepared, it should be used within one day.

Prepare the solution.
  1. Add 25 mL of distilled water to the bottle containing 0.5 g pepsin powder.
  2. Cap the bottle and shake gently to dissolve the pepsin powder. Once the pepsin solution is prepared, it should be used within one day.
Cut the brown paper bag into 8 squares, each approximately 8 cm × 8 cm.

In Activity 1, you will use an iodine-potassium iodide solution to test a potato starch solution and an albumin solution for the presence of starch. You will use the results of this test for comparison in Activity 5 to understand how starches are digested.
Add 5 mL of distilled water to test tubes 1, 2, and 3.
Shake the potato starch solution to ensure that it is mixed well. Add 20 drops of potato starch solution to test tube 2.
Shake the albumin solution to ensure that it is mixed well. Add 20 drops of albumin solution to test tube 3.
Add 4 drops of iodine-potassium iodide solution to test tubes 1, 2, and 3.

Observe the test tubes closely for 30 seconds and record any color changes in Data Table 1. For the best view, hold the test tube against a sheet of white paper to visualize the color. Photograph your results.
Dispose of the test tube contents in the trash or down the drain.
Clean and dry each test tube and graduated cylinder for the next activity.

Repeat Steps 1–7 using a few common food items such as honey, milk, fruit juice, fruit, flour, bread, crackers, cooking oils, meat, egg white, fish, and/or dried beans in place of the albumin and starch. Liquids can be used without dilution; solids should be mixed with distilled water.

In Activity 2, you will use the Biuret test to test a potato starch solution and an albumin solution for the presence of proteins. You will use the results of this test for comparison in Activity 4 to understand how proteins are digested.
Add 5 mL of distilled water to test tubes 1, 2, and 3.
Shake the albumin solution to ensure that it is mixed well. Add 10 drops of albumin solution to test tube 2.
Shake the potato starch solution to ensure that it is mixed well. Add 10 drops of potato starch solution to test tube 3.
Add 20 drops of Biuret reagent to test tubes 1, 2, and 3. Tap and swirl each tube to mix the contents completely.

Observe the test tubes closely for 30 seconds and record any changes in Data Table 2. For the best view, hold the test tube against a sheet of white paper to visualize the color. Photograph your results.
Dispose of the test tube contents in the trash or down the drain.
Clean and dry each test tube and graduated cylinder for the next activity.

Repeat Steps 1–7 using a few common food items such as honey, milk, fruit juice, fruit, flour, bread, crackers, cooking oils, meat, egg white, fish, and/or dried beans in place of the albumin and starch. Liquids can be used without dilution; solids should be mixed with distilled water.

In Activity 3, you will test various food substances from your home for the presence of lipids using a quick test for fats called the lipid streak test. You will use the results of the test for standard substances to determine the presence of lipids in unknown samples.

pages.title: Quick Test for Fats (9 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Quick Test for Fats (9 steps)

pageData.text: Before Proceeding, view the video:
Gather the required items.
Draw a circle approximately 2.5 cm in diameter in the center of each square of brown paper.

Label a square on the lower edge of each piece of paper for each of the following: (Unknown A–C may be drawn from the list of common food items such as honey, milk, fruit juice, fruit, bread, meat, egg white, etc.)
  1. Water
  2. Vegetable or olive oil
  3. Vinegar
  4. Salad dressing
  5. Mustard or ketchup
  6. Unknown A
  7. Unknown B
  8. Unknown C
Specify which substance you used in the Identity Column of Data Table 3.
Place a sample drop or gently rub the samples on the appropriately labeled square.
Allow the paper to dry for 15 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Turn over each piece of brown paper to visualize the results on the back of the paper. You may hold the paper up to the light for better visualization of results.
Record the results in Data Table 3: positive reaction (+) or negative reaction (−).
Photograph the 8 pieces of brown paper as a group for comparison.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 4, you will model the digestion of proteins in the stomach using hydrochloric acid and the enzyme <button class='glossary-text'>pepsin</button>. You will use the Biuret test and compare your color changes to the results of Activity 2 to determine if the protein has been broken down.

pages.title: Modeling Gastric Digestion of Protein (13 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Modeling Gastric Digestion of Protein (13 steps)

pageData.text: Relabel the test tubes 1a, 1b, 2a, and 2b.
Add warm water (35–40 °C) to one foam cup.

Dispense the appropriate liquids into each test tube as directed in the setup for modeling gastric digestion of protein (see Table 1). Shake the albumin solution before dispensing to ensure that it is mixed completely. Be sure to rinse the graduated cylinder with distilled water between uses. If you are using the dropper bottles or dropper pipets, you can estimate that 30 drops is equal to 1 mL.
Add 6 drops of Biuret reagent to test tubes 1a and 2a. Tap and swirl the tubes to mix the contents completely.
Hold the tube against a white sheet of paper to visualize the color. Record the color of the contents in Data Table 4.
Take a photograph of your test tubes with the labels clearly visible and a small sign to identify this step.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Transfer test tubes 1b and 2b to the foam cup with 35–40 °C water in it. Use the thermometer to monitor the water temperature, and add more warm water to the cup if the bath drops below 35 °C. Allow the tubes to incubate in the water bath for 45 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Remove the test tubes from the water bath and place them in the test tube rack.
Add 6 drops of Biuret reagent to test tubes 1b and 2b. Tap and swirl each tube to mix the contents completely.

Hold the tube against a white sheet of paper to visualize the color. Any color change you observe will be very subtle. Review the video on how to interpret Biuret color change to help you identify the color of each test tube. Record the color of the contents in Data Table 4.
Take a photograph of your test tubes with the labels clearly visible and a small sign to identify this step.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Dispose of the test tube contents in the trash or down the drain.
Clean and dry each test tube and graduated cylinder for the next activity.

In Activity 5, you will model the digestion of starches in the mouth by performing the iodine starch test on a crushed saltine and a masticated saltine. You will compare your color changes to the results of Activity 1 to determine if the starch has been broken down.

pages.title: Modeling Salivary Digestion of Starch (10 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Modeling Salivary Digestion of Starch (10 steps)

pageData.text: Place one saltine cracker on a sheet of paper towel.
Fold the paper towel in half and carefully crush the cracker into a fine powder using the bottom of a cup or container.
Carefully pour the cracker crumbs into one of the foam cups.
Add 10 mL of distilled water into the cup with the cracker crumbs. Use a plastic stirrer to mix the water and crumbs together until crumbs are uniformly wet.

Place a second saltine cracker in your mouth. Chew the cracker, without swallowing, for 1 minute. If the cracker is completely chewed before one minute is reached, continue to move the food in your mouth until the time is up.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Carefully spit all the contents of your mouth into the second foam cup. Avoid getting too much of the mixture on the sides of the cup.
Add 10 drops of iodine-potassium iodide solution to each cup. Thoroughly mix the contents of each cup for 30 seconds, using a different plastic stirrer for each.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Allow the cups to sit for 1 minute.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Briefly restir the contents of each cup with their respective stirrers and take a photograph of the inside of each foam cup with a small sign to identify this step.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Complete Data Table 5 and answer any remaining questions.

text: Dispose of the contents of each test tube, and any enzyme and/or substrate solutions down the drain. Large pieces of substrate, or very thick substrate pastes, may be best disposed of in household trash.
Dispose of leftover enzyme solutions down the drain. Let the water run for at least 30 seconds afterward.
Leftover hydrochloric acid may be discarded by pouring it slowly down the drain with copious tap water. Let the water run for at least 30 seconds afterward.
Used foam cups and pipets may be disposed of in the trash.
Wash and dry all reusable labware and return to the kit.
Clean and sanitize the work space.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: The molecular structures of starch, which is either chain-like or branched; glycogen, which is highly branched; and cellulose, which is like a sheet of chain-like molecules.
Figure 2: The chemical structure of an amino acid.

pageData.content: Figure 3. Saturated versus unsaturated fatty acids
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A saturated fatty acid molecule on top and an unsaturated fatty acid molecule on bottom.

pageData.content: Figure 4. Progress of reactions with and without enzymes
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Graph depicting the relationship between energy required in order to convert chemical reactants to products. Less energy is required in the presence of an enzyme to catalyze the reaction.
Figure 5: Diagram showing a substrate and enzyme coming together to form an enzyme-substrate complex, and the products separating from the enzyme.

pageData.content: Figure 6. Hydrolysis reaction of starch to maltose
pageData.altText: Figure 6: The enzyme amylase catalyzes hydrolysis of starch to maltose with the addition of water.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, prepare the test tubes, prepare starch, albumin, and pepsin solutions, and prepare paper squares. In Activity 1, you will conduct starch tests with controls, as well as three food samples. conduct protein tests with controls, as well as three food samples.  If so, yes go forward, if not go back. conduct quick tests for fats with eight food samples.  If so, yes go forward, if not go back. model the gastric digestion of protein. In Activity 5, you will model the salivary digestion of starch.

pageData.content: How to Interpret Biuret Color Change

data.title: Adenosine triphosphate
data.content: The main energy currency of the cell; abbreviated ATP

data.title: Amino acids
data.content: The monomers of proteins; they contain hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen in the general chemical formula NH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>–RCH–COOH, where –R represents either hydrogen, a functional group, a carbon chain, or a carbon ring structure

data.title: Amylase
data.content: An enzyme that catalyzes the breakdown of starch into its component sugars

data.title: Chyme
data.content: A semi-fluid mass of partially digested food and digestive secretions

data.title: Deoxyribonucleic acid
data.content: A double-stranded polymer that stores genetic information; abbreviated DNA

data.title: Disaccharides
data.content: Carbohydrates made up of two chemically-bonded monosaccharides; examples include sucrose (table sugar), maltose, and lactose

data.title: Enzymes
data.content: Specialized proteins that act as catalysts to speed up chemical reactions by lowering the activation energy required for the reaction

data.title: Fatty acid
data.content: A carboxylic acid chain found in lipids; it can be either saturated or unsaturated

data.title: Lipase
data.content: An enzyme the body uses to break down lipids

data.title: Monomers
data.content: The individual, repeating units of polymers

data.title: Monosaccharides
data.content: The monomers of carbohydrates and the least complex of the carbohydrate molecules; often called simple sugars

data.title: Nucleotides
data.content: The monomers of nucleic acids; they consist of a pentose (five-carbon) sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base

data.title: Pancreatin
data.content: A substance containing the pancreatic enzymes, trypsin, amylase, and lipase; also called pancreatic juice

data.title: Pepsin
data.content: A stomach enzyme that breaks down protein

data.title: Peptide bonds
data.content: The type of chemical bond formed between two molecules when the carboxyl group of one molecule reacts with the amino group of the other molecule

data.title: Polypeptides
data.content: Chains of many amino acids

data.title: Polysaccharides
data.content: The most complex carbohydrates, which contain several monosaccharides linked in various configurations

data.title: Ribonucleic acid
data.content: A single-stranded polymer that transmits genetic information; abbreviated RNA

data.title: Saturated
data.content: Describes a fatty acid chain composed entirely of carbon atoms joined by single covalent bonds

data.title: Triglycerides
data.content: A type of lipid that contains three fatty acid chains bonded to a glycerol molecule (a sugar alcohol)

data.title: Unsaturated
data.content: Describes a fatty acid chain that has one or more double bonds in its carbon chain, causing there to be two fewer hydrogen atoms in the chain per double bond
